awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Ultrasound-Assisted Biofabrication Of Biomimetic Soft Tissue Constructs With Aligned Fiber Organization
awd_abstract_narration:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) award project involves the use of ultrasound principles to aid in bioprinting of functional tissues with highly organized fibers as reinforcement, thereby providing for stronger functional biomanufactured tissue. This has been recognized as a serious technical limitation of existing bioprinting applications, and has far-reaching impacts. Perhaps the most immediate is the production of scaffolds for soft tissue reconstruction surgeries where the scaffold has improved mechanical properties. Long-term applications are significant and range from constructs for drug evaluation to replacement organs. The PI's education and outreach plan includes development of courses on biofabrication as well as a centralized biofabrication web-based knowledge resource, as well as extensive outreach to K-12 students and the broader bioprinting community. Specifically, the PI will develop a Bio-Design and Manufacturing summer workshop for high school students and collaborations with the North Carolina Science Museum. 

The use of a standing ultrasonic wave in additive manufacturing with cell-infused bionics leads to orientation in reinforcing fibers. Leveraging the PI's expertise in biomedical design and manufacturing, multidisciplinary collaborations, and lab capabilities, this project will generate new knowledge about fundamental material-process-structure-function interactions in the ultrasonic manipulation of 3D encapsulated cells, nanofibers and cell-secreted extracellular matrix (ECM). The outcomes will confirm if aligned polymer nanofibers within a hydrogel can guide fibrous ECM formation along their alignment trajectory better than aligned encapsulated cells alone (without nanofibers). The validated analytical and empirical models will provide a multivariate mapping of UAB parameter interrelationships with functionally-critical cellular and ECM responses. For the first time, the 3D-bioprinting of human anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) and annulus fibrosus tissue constructs with biomimetic ECM organization will be achieved.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
The ability to manufacture biological substitutes that mimic the unique multi-scale organization of natural tissues, which is important to the tissues' bio/mechanical functions, has remained a long time challenge in the field of tissue engineering and regenerative medicine. This project sought to address this challenge by studying the use of ultrasound to manipulate living cells and biologically-supportive additives into controlled patterns within three dimensional engineered tissue constructs during biofabrication. In particular, a new process/platform technology, referred to as ultrasound-assisted biofabrication (UAB) was designed, and the effects of critical process parameters on the structural, biological, and mechanical properties of 3D constructs were comprehensively characterized through several analytical and computational modeling and experimental design studies. The computational models highlighted the pressure/force distributions, thermal changes, and time required to organize micro-particles (e.g., cells, cell spheroids, collagen microaggregeates, biopolymer microfibers) into biomimetic patterns. In future, these models can be used to determine appropriate bioink and UAB configurations to achieve application-specific organization of interest to inform the physical fabrication of the desired tissue constructs. The experimental results correlated well with the predictive models, in general, and further elucidated the appropriate processing conditions under which patterned cells can remain viable and can subsequently secrete organized extracellular matrix over time. Based on the modeling and experimental characterization outcomes, the UAB technology was integrated with extrusion and digital light processing (DLP)-based bioprinting systems, and prototypes of knee meniscus, ligaments, and annulus fibrosus were fabricated to recapitulate the tissue-specific micro- and macro-structural organizations. The research outcomes of this project are promising and are expected to support the development of new 3D biofabrication platforms and tissue engineered medical products in future. Furthermore, the project directly impacted the education, research training, and professional development of at least three undergraduate and six graduate research assistants. The knowledge from this project was also conveyed to several K-12, undergraduate, and graduate students through multiple design and manufacturing courses and middle and high school outreach activities every year. In addition, the students and PI disseminated the project efforts and outcomes to various communities through peer-reviewed articles, international conferences, invited seminars, and public outreach events such as university open houses. Overall, this project has contributed to advances in 3D biofabrication science, technology and education. 

 


Last Modified: 09/27/2023
Modified by: Rohan A Shirwaiker
